contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox political party |name = Liberal Party |native_name = Liberalna stranka |logo = [[File:LS Logo.svg|150px|Logo]] |colorcode = blue |founder = [[Vlado Gotovac]] |leader1_title = |leader1_name = |leader2_title = |leader2_name = |founded = {{Start date|1998|1|24|df=y}} |dissolved = {{End date|2006|4|27|df=y}} |split = [[Croatian Social Liberal Party]] |merged = Croatian Social Liberal Party |ideology = [[Social liberalism]] |position = |international = [[Liberal International]] |european = [[European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party]] |europarl = |colors = Blue and yellow |symbol = |country = Croatia |footnotes = }} '''Liberal Party''' ({{lang-hr|Liberalna stranka}} or '''LS''') was a [[Croatia]]n political party active between January 1998 and April 2006.<ref name="hidra-profil"/> During its existence the party ran in two general elections (in 2000 and 2003) and in each election won two seats in the 151-seat [[Croatian parliament|Sabor]]. LS was a member of [[Liberal International]] and the [[European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party]]. Its last leader was Zlatko Benašić. The party was formed in January 1998 following a party split in November 1997 when a faction led by [[Vlado Gotovac]], then chairman of [[Croatian Social Liberal Party]] (HSLS), left the party because of internal power struggles which resulted in former chairman [[Dražen Budiša]] taking back control of the party.<ref name="slobodna">{{cite news|url=http://www.slobodnadalmacija.com/Hrvatska/tabid/66/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/88158/Default.aspx|title=HDZ nastao, a HSLS skoro nestao u raskolu |last=Marjanović|first=Vedran|coauthors=Luetić, Tomislav|date=18 January 2010|work=[[Slobodna Dalmacija]]|language=Croatian|accessdate=22 October 2011}}</ref> Gotovac was joined by other prominent liberals such as [[Osijek]] mayor [[Zlatko Kramarić]] and historian [[Ivo Banac]]. In 2000, the party had two representatives in the [[Croatian Parliament|Parliament]] and had one minister in a coalition government with the much larger [[Social Democratic Party of Croatia]]. LS confirmed their two representatives in the Parliament in the 2003 elections, in an alliance with the social democrats, but became part of the opposition. After the 2003 election party leader [[Ivo Banac]] announced the merger of LS with the [[Croatian People's Party]] and [[LIBRA]] into one big liberal party, but this initiative was opposed by faction led by [[Zlatko Kramarić]]. Banac was replaced at the party convention. After the 2005 local elections Zlatko Kramarić started merger negotiations with the [[Croatian Social Liberal Party]]. That prompted a group of dissidents in [[Split (city)|Split]] to form a new party called [[Dalmatian Liberal Party]]. Liberal Party formally ceased to exist with all of its membership and party infrastructure re-joining HSLS in April 2006.<ref name="hidra-profil">{{cite web|url=http://www.hidra.hr/politicke_stranke/imenik_stranaka_registriranih_u_rh_od_1990_godine/%28iframesrc%29/aHR0cDovL2hpZHJhLnNyY2UuaHIvd2VicGFjLWhpZHJhLXRoczIvP3JtPXJlc3VsdHMmYW1wO3Nob3dfZnVsbD0xJmFtcDtmPUlEdGhzJmFtcDt2PTAzMjg2MA==|title=Liberalna stranka|date=18 October 2011|publisher=HIDRA|language=Croatian|accessdate=24 October 2011}}</ref> ==Presidents== *[[Vlado Gotovac]] (1998–2000) *[[Božo Kovačević (politician)|Božo Kovačević]] (acting) (2000) *[[Zlatko Kramarić]] (2000–2003) *[[Ivo Banac]] (2003–2004) *Zlatko Benašić (2004–2006) ==Election history== The following is a summary of the party's results in legislative elections for the [[Croatian parliament]]. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" |- !width="120"|Election!!width="160"|In coalition with!!width="100"|Votes won<br /> <small> (Coalition totals)</small>!!width="100"|Percentage!!width="100"|Seats won<br /> <small>(LS only)</small>!!width="100"|Change |- |[[Croatian parliamentary election, 2000|January 2000]] |[[Croatian Peasant Party|HSS]]–[[Istrian Democratic Assembly|IDS]]–[[Croatian People's Party – Liberal Democrats|HNS]]–[[Social Democratic Action of Croatia|ASH]] |align="right"|432,527 |align="right"|14.70 |align="center"|2 / 151 |{{NA}} |- |[[Croatian parliamentary election, 2003|November 2003]] |[[Social Democratic Party of Croatia|SDP]]–[[Istrian Democratic Assembly|IDS]]–[[LIBRA]] |align="right"|560,593 |align="right"|22.60 |align="center"|2 / 151 |align="center"|±0 |- |} ==See also== *[[Liberalism in Croatia]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Social liberal parties]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Croatia]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1998]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 2006]]
